options.label: B

options.label: C

options.text: It is absorbed by the liver

options.text: To avoid falling victim to the bends

options.label: C

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: To release the gas through their breath

options.label: C

title: What did democracy really mean in Athens? - Melissa Schwartzberg

multiple-choice.question: **Knowledge**

options.label: A
options.text: The ancient Athenians used elections to fill most positions in their government.

options.label: B
options.text: The Athenian system of government relied on a 500 member governing council called the Boule.

options.label: C
options.text: The Athenians used sortition, a process of randomized selection, to choose citizens for government positions.

options.label: D
options.text: The Athenians only allowed citizens over 50 years old to participate in government.

multiple-choice.question: **Comprehension**

options.label: A
options.text: The Athenian system of government was a direct democracy where citizens made decisions on their own behalf.

options.label: B
options.text: The Athenian system of government relied on a professional class of politicians to make decisions.

options.label: C
options.text: The Athenian system of government was a representative democracy where citizens elected representatives to make decisions.

options.label: D
options.text: The Athenian system of government was an aristocracy where decisions were made by the best.

multiple-choice.question: **Application**

options.label: A
options.text: If you were to implement the Athenian system of government in your country today, you would need to ensure that all citizens have the same level of education and expertise.

options.label: B
options.text: The Athenian system of government could be effective in a country with a small population and simple needs.

options.label: C
options.text: The Athenian system of government could be effective in a country with a large population and complex needs.

options.label: D
options.text: The Athenian system of government is only suitable for small countries.

multiple-choice.question: **Analysis**

options.label: A
options.text: The Athenian system of government was successful because it allowed citizens to participate directly in decision-making.

options.label: B
options.text: The Athenian system of government was successful because it relied on a professional class of politicians to make decisions.

options.label: C
options.text: The Athenian system of government was successful because it allowed citizens to choose their representatives through elections.

options.label: D
options.text: The Athenian system of government was successful because it was a representative democracy where citizens elected representatives to make decisions.

multiple-choice.question: **Synthesis**

options.label: A
options.text: The Athenian system of government could be revived today by implementing sortition and strict term limits.

options.label: B
options.text: The Athenian system of government could be revived today by implementing a professional class of politicians.

options.label: C
options.text: The Athenian system of government could be revived today by implementing a representative democracy where citizens elect representatives to make decisions.

options.label: D
options.text: The Athenian system of government could be revived today by implementing an aristocracy where decisions are made by the best.

multiple-choice.question: **Evaluation**

options.label: A
options.text: The Athenian system of government is a more effective form of democracy than representative democracy.

options.label: B
options.text: The Athenian system of government is a less effective form of democracy than representative democracy.

options.label: C
options.text: The Athenian system of government is as effective as representative democracy.

options.label: D
options.text: The Athenian system of government is more effective in small countries than in large countries.

multiple-choice.question: **Knowledge**

options.label: A
options.text: The Athenian system of government excluded women and slaves from participating in decision-making.

options.label: B
options.text: The Athenian system of government included all citizens in decision-making.

options.label: C
options.text: The Athenian system of government only allowed citizens over 50 years old to participate in decision-making.

options.label: D
options.text: The Athenian system of government did not exclude anyone from participating in decision-making.

multiple-choice.question: **Comprehension**

options.label: A
options.text: The Athenian system of government relied on a 500 member governing council called the Boule to set the agenda and evaluate proposals.

options.label: B
options.text: The Athenian system of government relied on a professional class of politicians to make decisions.

options.label: C
options.text: The Athenian system of government relied on citizens to make decisions directly.

options.label: D
options.text: The Athenian system of government relied on sortition to choose citizens for government positions.

multiple-choice.question: **Analysis**

options.label: A
options.text: The Athenian system of government was successful because it allowed citizens to participate directly in decision-making.

options.label: B
options.text: The Athenian system of government was successful because it relied on a professional class of politicians to make decisions.

options.label: C
options.text: The Athenian system of government was successful because it allowed citizens to choose their representatives through elections.

options.label: D
options.text: The Athenian system of government was successful because it was a representative democracy where citizens elected representatives to make decisions.

multiple-choice.question: **Evaluation**

options.label: A
options.text: The Athenian system of government is a more effective form of democracy than representative democracy.

options.label: B
options.text: The Athenian system of government is a less effective form of democracy than representative democracy.

options.label: C
options.text: The Athenian system of government is as effective as representative democracy.

options.label: D
options.text: The Athenian system of government is more effective in small countries than in large countries.

title: Where did Earth’s water come from? - Zachary Metz

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about water, as described in the passage?

options.label: C
options.text: C: It has no taste, color, or smell.

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of the Earth is covered by water, according to the passage?
What is the primary function of the Earth's atmosphere, as described in the passage?

options.label: A
options.text: To trap water on the planet's surface.

options.label: C
options.text: To allow water to evaporate back into space.

options.label: D
options.text: To create a layer of volcanic gases.

multiple-choice.question: What is the process by which stars form heavier elements, such as oxygen, as described in the passage?
What is the theory that suggests water arrived on Earth through ice-bearing comets or asteroids?
What is the mineral chemical composition of carbonaceous chondrite meteorites that formed shortly after the birth of our solar system, as described in the passage?

options.label: B
options.text: Similar to rocks on Earth and samples from an asteroid that formed at the same time as our planet.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the discovery that carbonaceous chondrite meteorites contain water and have a mineral chemical composition similar to rocks on Earth and samples from an asteroid that formed at the same time as our planet, as described in the passage?

options.label: A
options.text: It suggests that life may have formed much earlier than previously thought.

options.label: B
options.text: It supports the theory that water arrived on Earth through ice-bearing comets or asteroids.

options.label: C
options.text: It contradicts the theory that water arrived on Earth through its initial formation.

options.label: D
options.text: It is irrelevant to the origin of water on Earth.

multiple-choice.question: What is the process by which molten rock in the Earth's core releases volcanic gases to the surface, as described in the passage?
What is the theory that suggests that water arrived on Earth when its first atmosphere formed through a process called outgassing?
What is the current understanding of the origin of water on Earth, as described in the passage?

options.label: A
options.text: It is known that water arrived on Earth through its initial formation.

options.label: B
options.text: It is known that water arrived on Earth through later impacts.

options.label: C
options.text: It is known that water arrived on Earth through a combination of its initial formation and later impacts.

options.label: D
options.text: It is not yet definitively known where the water on Earth came from.

title: Plato’s Allegory of the Cave - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: Who is the ancient Greek philosopher mentioned in the transcript as having suggested that life is like being chained up in a cave, forced to watch shadows flitting across a stone wall?

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: Why it’s so hard to cure HIV/AIDS - Janet Iwasa

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary method of HIV transmission?
What is the name of the stage of HIV infection where the patient is in serious danger of contracting deadly infections?
What is the primary target of HIV infection in the human body?
What is the primary function of antiretroviral therapy in HIV-positive patients?

options.label: B
options.text: To manage levels of HIV and prevent T cell counts from getting low

multiple-choice.question: How do the most commonly prescribed antiretroviral drugs work?

options.label: A
options.text: By preventing the viral genome from being copied and incorporated into a host cell's DNA

options.label: B
options.text: By preventing the virus from maturing or assembling

options.label: C
options.text: By activating all cells harboring the HIV genetic information

options.label: D
options.text: By cutting the HIV DNA out of cells genomes altogether

multiple-choice.question: What is the major catch of antiretroviral therapy for HIV-positive patients?

options.label: A
options.text: That it is not effective in preventing T cell counts from getting low

options.label: B
options.text: That patients must keep taking their drugs for the rest of their lives

options.label: C
options.text: That it is only effective in treating opportunistic infections

options.label: D
options.text: That it is not available in all parts of the world

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why HIV-positive patients in Sub-Saharan Africa do not have access to antiretrovirals?

options.label: C
options.text: A mix of political, economic, and cultural barriers

multiple-choice.question: What is one potential approach to developing a true cure for HIV?

options.label: A
options.text: Using a drug to activate all cells harboring the HIV genetic information

options.label: B
options.text: Using genetic tools to cut the HIV DNA out of cells genomes altogether

multiple-choice.question: Why is a cure for HIV still a topic of research despite the availability of antiretroviral therapy?

options.label: A
options.text: Because antiretroviral therapy is not effective in preventing T cell counts from getting low

options.label: B
options.text: Because patients must keep taking their drugs for the rest of their lives

options.label: C
options.text: Because not everyone in the world has access to antiretrovirals

options.label: D
options.text: Because a cure would provide a more permanent solution to HIV/AIDS

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the case of the man who was cured of HIV in 2008?

options.label: A
options.text: It shows that antiretroviral therapy is not effective in preventing T cell counts from getting low

options.label: B
options.text: It shows that a cure for HIV is possible

options.label: C
options.text: It shows that HIV is not a serious disease

options.label: D
options.text: It shows that HIV is highly contagious

title: How does the thyroid manage your metabolism? - Emma Bryce

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the thyroid gland in the human body?

options.label: C
options.text: To make sure that the cells in the body are working properly

multiple-choice.question: Which two hormones are produced by the thyroid gland that play a crucial role in regulating metabolism?
What is the role of the pituitary gland in relation to the thyroid gland?

options.label: A
options.text: To produce hormones that stimulate the thyroid gland

options.label: B
options.text: To produce hormones that inhibit the thyroid gland

options.label: C
options.text: To oversee the thyroid gland's tasks and ensure it knows when to send out hormones

multiple-choice.question: A person with hyperthyroidism experiences a higher metabolism, which is signaled by a faster heartbeat, constant hunger, and rapid weight loss. What is the primary cause of this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: The thyroid gland sends out too few hormones

options.label: B
options.text: The thyroid gland is not functioning properly due to a disease or growth

options.label: C
options.text: The pituitary gland is not producing enough thyroid-stimulating hormone

options.label: D
options.text: The thyroid gland is not being controlled by the pituitary gland

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary difference between hyperthyroidism and hypothyroidism?

options.label: A
options.text: Hyperthyroidism causes weight gain, while hypothyroidism causes weight loss

options.label: B
options.text: Hyperthyroidism causes a slower metabolism, while hypothyroidism causes an overactive metabolism

options.label: C
options.text: Hyperthyroidism causes a higher metabolism, while hypothyroidism causes a lower metabolism

options.label: D
options.text: Hyperthyroidism causes fatigue, while hypothyroidism causes anxiety

multiple-choice.question: A person with hypothyroidism experiences weight gain, sluggishness, sensitivity to cold, swollen joints, and feeling low. What is the primary cause of this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: The thyroid gland sends out too many hormones

options.label: B
options.text: The thyroid gland is not functioning properly due to a disease or growth

options.label: C
options.text: The pituitary gland is not producing enough thyroid-stimulating hormone

options.label: D
options.text: The thyroid gland is not being controlled by the pituitary gland

multiple-choice.question: What is a possible treatment for hyperthyroidism and hypothyroidism?

options.label: A
options.text: Surgery to remove the thyroid gland

options.label: B
options.text: Medication to stimulate or inhibit the thyroid gland

options.label: C
options.text: A change in diet to regulate metabolism

options.label: D
options.text: A change in exercise routine to regulate metabolism

multiple-choice.question: The thyroid gland plays a crucial role in regulating metabolism, growth, and reproduction. What would happen if the thyroid gland were to malfunction?

options.label: A
options.text: The body's cells would not be able to consume oxygen and nutrients

options.label: B
options.text: The body's cells would not be able to use energy, grow, and reproduce

options.label: C
options.text: The body's metabolism would slow down

options.label: D
options.text: The body's metabolism would speed up

multiple-choice.question: The thyroid gland is a small organ that wields enormous power over the body. What is the primary benefit of a healthy thyroid gland?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows the body to filter blood

options.label: B
options.text: It allows the body to regulate body temperature

options.label: C
options.text: It allows the body's cells to use energy, grow, and reproduce

options.label: D
options.text: It allows the body to produce digestive enzymes

multiple-choice.question: The thyroid gland is controlled by the pituitary gland, which oversees its tasks and ensures it knows when to send out hormones. What is the primary benefit of this system?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows the thyroid gland to function independently

options.label: B
options.text: It allows the pituitary gland to control the thyroid gland's functions

options.label: C
options.text: It allows the body's cells to use energy, grow, and reproduce

options.label: D
options.text: It allows the body's metabolism to slow down

title: Did Shakespeare write his plays? - Natalya St. Clair and Aaron Williams

multiple-choice.question: Who is often credited with formalizing the method of stylometry in the late 1800s?
What is the primary idea behind stylometry?

options.label: A
options.text: Each writer's style is unique and can be used to identify them

options.label: B
options.text: Stylometry is a method of analyzing syntax, grammar, and semantics

options.label: C
options.text: Stylometry is a tool for plagiarism detection

options.label: D
options.text: Stylometry is a method of analyzing vocabulary

multiple-choice.question: What are some characteristics that remain fairly uniform among individual works of a writer?

options.label: A
options.text: Average sentence length, arrangement of words, and number of occurrences of a particular word

multiple-choice.question: What does the tightness of data points give us in statistics?

options.label: A
options.text: The variance, an expected range for our data

options.label: B
options.text: The standard deviation, a measure of spread

options.label: C
options.text: The mean, a measure of central tendency

options.label: D
options.text: The median, a measure of central tendency

multiple-choice.question: How can stylometric analysis help us determine the authorship of a work?

options.label: A
options.text: By analyzing the syntax, grammar, and semantics of the text

options.label: B
options.text: By examining the vocabulary and tone of the text

options.label: C
options.text: By comparing the text to the known works of a writer

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary limitation of stylometric analysis?

options.label: A
options.text: It cannot capture the beauty of the sentiments and emotions expressed in a text

options.label: B
options.text: It is limited to analyzing vocabulary and tone

options.label: C
options.text: It is limited to analyzing syntax, grammar, and semantics

options.label: D
options.text: It is not a reliable method of authorship identification

multiple-choice.question: What is Principal Component Analysis (PCA)?

options.label: B
options.text: A tool for reducing multidimensional space into simple principal components

multiple-choice.question: What did the results of the stylometric analysis show?

options.label: A
options.text: That Francis Bacon and Shakespeare are the same person

options.label: B
options.text: That Shakespeare worked with Christopher Marlowe on "Henry VI," parts one and two

options.label: C
options.text: That Shakespeare is none other than Shakespeare

multiple-choice.question: What are some potential applications of stylometric analysis?

options.label: A
options.text: Determining the authorship of a work, analyzing vocabulary, and detecting plagiarism

options.label: B
options.text: Analyzing syntax, grammar, and semantics, and determining the authorship of a work

options.label: C
options.text: Determining the authorship of a work and analyzing vocabulary

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of stylometric analysis in the context of Shakespeare's works?

options.label: A
options.text: It can help us determine the authorship of his works

options.label: B
options.text: It can help us understand the structure and style of his works

options.label: C
options.text: It can help us understand the beauty of the sentiments and emotions expressed in his works

options.label: A
options.text: If the biggest number is five or six

options.label: B
options.text: If the biggest number is one, two, three, or four

options.label: C
options.text: If both dice show a five or six

options.label: D
options.text: If both dice show a one, two, three, or four

multiple-choice.question: What is the approximate chance of player two winning each match?
Why does the first glance at the game's rules suggest that player one has an advantage?

options.label: A
options.text: Because player one has four winning numbers

options.label: B
options.text: Because player two has two winning numbers

options.label: C
options.text: Because the chance of each number being the greatest is not the same

multiple-choice.question: A five or six on the dice means a win for which player?
What is the joint probability of getting a one, two, three, or four on both dice?
Why does the chance of player two winning not necessarily mean they will win in a single game?

options.label: B
options.text: Because the probability of each outcome is not the same

options.label: C
options.text: Because the result of each die roll is independent from the other

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the frequency of a specific outcome, like a player two win, if you repeat the random events many times?
Why is it impossible to predict the exact outcome of a single game of dice?

options.label: B
options.text: Because the probability of each outcome is not the same

options.label: C
options.text: Because the result of each die roll is independent from the other

multiple-choice.question: What is the theoretical probability of player two winning if you played 36 games as player two?
If you sat on the desert island playing dice forever, what would eventually happen to the number of games player two wins?

options.label: D
options.text: It would approach 56% of the total games

title: What does the pancreas do? - Emma Bryce

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the pancreas in the human body?
What is the name of the hormone that tells the body's cells and liver to release stored sugars back into the bloodstream?
What happens to the blood sugar levels if the pancreas releases insulin after a big meal?
How does the pancreas control the amount of sugar in the blood?
What is the condition known as when the pancreas is weakened by disease and can no longer produce insulin?
What happens to the body's cells and liver if the pancreas releases glucagon when blood sugar is low?

options.label: A
options.text: They release stored sugars back into the bloodstream

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of insulin in the body?
How does the pancreas work with the body's cells and liver to maintain a healthy balance of sugar levels?
What are the consequences of a faulty pancreas that can no longer produce insulin?

options.label: A
options.text: Heart attacks, kidney failure, and strokes

multiple-choice.question: What is the importance of the pancreas in maintaining a healthy balance of sugar levels in the body?

title: How one piece of legislation divided a nation - Ben Labaree, Jr.

multiple-choice.question: What was the main reason for the collapse of the Second Party System in 1850?

options.label: A
options.text: The rise of the Republican Party

options.label: B
options.text: The dominance of the Democratic Party

options.label: C
options.text: It led to the party's demise

options.label: D

options.label: C
options.text: The death of five pro-slavery farmers

options.label: D
options.text: The end of the conflict in Kansas

multiple-choice.question: What was the main consequence of the Kansas-Nebraska Act on the Democratic Party?

options.label: C
options.text: It led to the party's division along sectional lines

options.label: D
options.text: It merged with the Republican Party

multiple-choice.question: Who was the first Republican presidential candidate?

options.label: A
options.text: It had no impact on the war

options.label: C
options.text: C: It made the war more likely

title: The sonic boom problem - Katerina Kaouri

multiple-choice.question: What was the significant achievement in the history of human progress related to speed?

options.label: A
options.text: Breaking the world record for the fastest car

options.label: C
options.text: The breaking of the sound barrier

multiple-choice.question: Who was the American military pilot who first broke the sound barrier in 1947?

What is the shape formed by the Mach cone where it meets the ground, leaving a trail known as the boom carpet?
How do scientists study sonic booms to predict their path in the atmosphere, where they will land, and how loud they will be?

options.label: A
options.text: By using computer models and the Navier-Stokes equations

options.label: B
options.text: By observing the effects of sonic booms on the environment

options.label: C
options.text: By conducting experiments with supersonic aircraft

options.label: D
options.text: By studying the behavior of other animals that create sonic booms

multiple-choice.question: What is the pressure signature known as the N-wave that results from solving the Navier-Stokes equations to find the variation of pressure in the air due to a supersonic aircraft flying through it?

options.label: C
options.text: A pressure wave with two booms

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the equation used to find the variation of pressure in the air due to a supersonic aircraft flying through it?
What is the phenomenon where approaching objects sound higher pitched, caused by the Doppler effect?
Which of the following animals may have been capable of cracking its tail faster than sound, possibly to deter predators?
What is the name of the type of shrimp that can create a similar shock wave underwater, stunning or even killing prey at a distance with just a snap of their oversized claw?

title: How do your kidneys work? - Emma Bryce

multiple-choice.question: What are the two main roles of the kidneys in the human body?

options.label: A
options.text: To filter the blood and produce urine

options.label: B
options.text: To produce hormones and regulate body temperature

options.label: C
options.text: To digest food and absorb nutrients

multiple-choice.question: How many liters of blood pass through the kidneys every 24 hours?
What is the function of the glomerulus in the nephron?

options.label: A
options.text: To detect waste products in the blood

options.label: B
options.text: To filter the blood and allow certain ingredients to pass through

options.label: C
options.text: To produce hormones and regulate body temperature

options.label: D
options.text: To digest food and absorb nutrients

multiple-choice.question: If the kidney detects too much water in the blood, what will it do?

options.label: A
options.text: Release more water into the bloodstream

options.label: B
options.text: Send the extra water to the bladder to be removed

multiple-choice.question: What would happen if the kidneys were not able to filter the blood properly?

options.label: A
options.text: The body would become too hydrated

options.label: B
options.text: The body would become too dehydrated

options.label: C
options.text: The body would accumulate waste products and eventually expire

options.label: D
options.text: The body would not be able to produce hormones

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the tubules in the nephron?

options.label: A
options.text: To filter the blood and allow certain ingredients to pass through

options.label: B
options.text: To detect waste products in the blood and redirect them as urine

options.label: C
options.text: To produce hormones and regulate body temperature

options.label: D
options.text: To digest food and absorb nutrients

multiple-choice.question: How do the kidneys regulate the amount of water in the body?

options.label: A
options.text: By increasing the production of urine when the body is dehydrated

options.label: B
options.text: By decreasing the production of urine when the body is dehydrated

options.label: C
options.text: By releasing water into the bloodstream when the body is dehydrated

options.label: D
options.text: By increasing the production of urine when the body is hydrated

multiple-choice.question: What would happen if the kidneys were not able to produce the hormone erythropoietin?

options.label: A
options.text: The body would become too hydrated

options.label: B
options.text: The body would become too dehydrated

options.label: C
options.text: The body would not be able to produce red blood cells

options.label: D
options.text: The body would not be able to regulate its fluid levels

multiple-choice.question: What is the main function of the nephrons in the kidneys?

options.label: A
options.text: To filter the blood and produce urine

options.label: B
options.text: To produce hormones and regulate body temperature

options.label: C
options.text: To digest food and absorb nutrients

multiple-choice.question: Why are the kidneys able to keep the body's fluid levels stable?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are able to filter the blood and produce urine

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are able to produce hormones and regulate body temperature

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are able to digest food and absorb nutrients

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are able to breathe and circulate oxygen

title: Why Shakespeare loved iambic pentameter - David T. Freeman and Gregory Taylor

multiple-choice.question: What was William Shakespeare primarily known for, despite being famous for his plays?

options.label: B
options.text: His ability to write in different poetic meters

options.label: D
options.text: His use of stress in language

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for a certain number of stressed and unstressed syllables forming a distinct unit in a line of verse?

What is the name of Shakespeare's favorite meter, where each line of verse is made up of five two-syllable iambs?
Why did Shakespeare choose iambic pentameter for certain moments in his plays, rather than other poetic meters?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it was easy for his actors to memorize and for the audience to understand

options.label: B
options.text: Because it was naturally suited to the English language

options.label: C
options.text: Because it followed the rhythm of the heart

What is the term for the natural rhythm of the heart, which Shakespeare's most poetic lines often follow?

title: Why do buildings fall in earthquakes? - Vicki V. May

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary cause of building collapse during an earthquake?

options.label: A
options.text: The ground beneath the building shaking violently

options.label: C
options.text: Displacement of the foundation and lower levels, sending shock waves through the rest of the structure

multiple-choice.question: What is the main factor that determines a building's response to an earthquake?

options.label: B
options.text: The building's material type and height

options.label: C
options.text: The building's location and soil type

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between a building's mass and its natural frequency?
What is the phenomenon that occurs when the frequency of the earthquake's seismic waves matches the natural frequency of a building?
What is the effect of resonance on a building's vibration?
What is the purpose of base isolation in earthquake engineering?

options.label: A
options.text: To absorb shocks and limit deformation using flexible layers

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between a building's height and its stiffness?
What is the role of seismologists in earthquake engineering?

options.label: A
options.text: To predict the frequency of earthquake motions at building sites

options.label: B
options.text: To design buildings to withstand earthquakes

options.label: C
options.text: To analyze the effects of earthquakes on buildings

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of low frequencies of motion on buildings?

options.label: A
options.text: Causes more damage to taller and more flexible buildings

options.label: B
options.text: Causes more damage to shorter and stiffer buildings

multiple-choice.question: What is the key to preventing resonance-induced collapses in buildings?

options.label: B
options.text: Working with geologists and seismologists to predict the frequency of earthquake motions at building sites

options.label: C
options.text: Using innovative systems to absorb shocks and limit deformation

title: McDonald's Cup Sizes Around The World

options.label: D

title: How do the lungs work? - Emma Bryce

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the respiratory system?

options.label: A
options.text: To filter out waste from the bloodstream

options.label: B
options.text: To transport oxygen to the body's cells

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the autonomic nervous system in breathing?

options.label: C
options.text: To send signals to the muscles around the lungs to flatten the diaphragm

multiple-choice.question: What is the process by which oxygen and carbon dioxide are exchanged in the lungs?
What is the function of the alveoli in the lungs?

options.label: A
options.text: To filter out waste from the bloodstream

options.label: B
options.text: To transport oxygen to the body's cells

options.label: C
options.text: To exchange oxygen and carbon dioxide

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of hemoglobin in the exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide?

options.label: A
options.text: To transport oxygen to the body's cells

options.label: B
options.text: To unload carbon dioxide into the lungs

multiple-choice.question: What is the average number of times the lungs inhale and exhale per minute?

options.label: B
options.text: By flattening the diaphragm and contracting the intercostal muscles

options.label: C
options.text: By relaxing the diaphragm and contracting the intercostal muscles

options.label: D
options.text: By contracting the diaphragm and relaxing the intercostal muscles

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the bronchioles in the respiratory system of the lungs?

options.label: A
options.text: To filter out waste from the bloodstream

options.label: B
options.text: To transport oxygen to the body's cells

options.label: C
options.text: To divide into smaller passages to facilitate gas exchange

multiple-choice.question: What is the most critical aspect of the respiratory system that we do not have to worry about remembering?
